If you want to learn, then build on something that's already there. Fix a bug, or add a new feature. Learning by building a new system will making learning much more complicated because you have to worry about design and architecture and other aspects.
Decide what you want to learn (language, framework, tool, etc) then find an existing project that uses it and start working on it.
If you want to learn about design and architecture, then read a book on the topic.

Well like everyone's saying, essentially you need to narrow the scope. Wordpress didn't start where it's currently at. It started as a small blog system, didn't even make it into a fully extendable blog engine until sometime later.
So start at the base, grow from there. If it's a blog engine you intend on building, then build a blog first. Going from there on, is a rather steep climb uphill.
Like Amr Eldib and Muhammad Negm have suggested, contribute to some small open source project first. Build on top of something already existing and carry on from there.

I've yet to find a book or a group of books that are comprehensive enough to teach you about software design and architecture, it's a rather broad topic. Multidisciplinary and to know enough about it is to spend a life time engineering software.
Everybody starts somewhere, so start small and grow from there. You'll pick up a lot along the way.

Good luck.
